results.title: Flame of Persia
results.brief_description: A historical, geographical and descriptive account of Persia/Iran including the celebration of 25 centuries of monarchy. Depicts the Shah of Iran discussing Persian industry and pride. Narrated by Orson Welles.

results.title: Flame cutting
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Gas Welding”.
Demonstrates the correct adjustment for flame cutting, which is the result of a chemical reaction between a ferrous chemical and oxygen.

results.title: Flags = Zastave
results.creator_credit: Zoran Jovanovic, Nancy Karkowsky and Neoplanta Film
results.brief_description: Zoran Jovanovic, in simple line drawings, explores man’s complex relationship to one of his most important symbols - the flag. Only women, Jovanovic implies, see the flag not as symbol but as fabric. Animation by Predrag Pantovic and Slavomir Calic.

results.title: Fixed vs floating exchange rates (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Monash University, Open Learning Agency of Australia and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course examines the history of exchange rates in contemporary capitalism. After World War II, exchange rates were fixed to the value of the US dollar which in turn was fixed to the price of gold. Over the 1960’s, however, the rise of speculation on international currencies saw exchange rates fluctuate at such an unstable rate that in 1971 the US government decided to allow its currency to be determined by the market rather than be affixed to gold prices. Since 1973 the value of currency has been determined by market forces rather than by being fixed to government determined rates. Using the example of the 1970s Oil Crisis, a panel of economists argue that market-determined exchange rates allow for greater flexibility.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, Monash University, Open Learning Agency of Australia and ABC-TV (Australia)

Since 1973 the value of currency has been determined by market forces rather than by being fixed to government determined rates. results.title: Fixed for death
results.creator_credit: Pauline Shaw and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Facts Are These”.
Investigates drug addiction among the under twenties. Includes group discussion with registered addicts at a hospital in Birmingham, showing their apathy and disgust. Considers the effects on the families of addicts. Points out the dangers of becoming hooked by experimentation.

results.title: Five towns
results.creator_credit: Terry Bishop and Green Park Productions
results.brief_description: The pottery industry seen though the eyes of a young London girl marrying into a typical potteries family. The film tells of the life of the people in the potteries and of the great industry in which they work. It shows ways in which conditions of work are in process of being modernised. Factory sequences were shot at the Crown Staffordshire Pottery, Fenton and the Wedgwood Pottery.

results.title: Five times dizzy. - Episodes 7-12.
results.creator_credit: John Eastway, Tom Jeffrey, Australian Children's Television Foundation, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Samson Film Services
results.brief_description: The final three episodes in the dramatisation of Nadia Wheatley’s award winning book about a family of Greek immigrants in Sydney’s Newtown, their homesick grandmother and the inhabitants of the street in which they live, as seen through the eyes of Mareka, the young daughter.

results.title: Five times dizzy. - Episodes 1-6.
results.creator_credit: John Eastway, Tom Jeffrey, Australian Children's Television Foundation, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Samson Film Services
results.brief_description: The first three episodes in a dramatisation of Nadia Wheatley’s award winning book. Mareka would be quite happy in the milk bar in Newtown, even though it is so far from Greece, if it wasn’t for the Wilson kids giving her a hard time. But her Yaya, her grandmother, has only recently arrived in Australia and feels lost and unhappy. If only Mareka could find her Yaya something to do. Then she has an idea. But it’s such a big idea she feels dizzy.
